   HPI:
    66 year old man with PMHx lung cancer 6 yrs ago, s/p RUL lobectomy (no
   chemo or XRT), as well as spondolithiasis s/p two laminectomies.  He
   initially presented to [**Hospital 755**] Hospital in mid-[**Month (only) 539**].  He lives in
   [**State 5568**], although he and his wife have been in the process of moving
   back to [**Location (un) 23**].  About two weeks after returning from [**State 5568**] he began
   to have lower back pain, first on the right and then on the left as
   well.  He then developed fevers and a cough.  He was also
   intermittently confused.  CT/MRI of the head and spine notable only for
   a intervertebral disc protrusion.  He also developed a progressive
   leukocytosis, but all cultures have remained negative.  He developed a
   facial rash while at [**Location (un) 755**], with a biopsy consistent with Sweet
   syndrome.  This resolved with steroids.  A bone marrow biopsy
   reportedly showed myelodysplasia bot no frank malignancy.  He was
   briefly on broad-spectrum antibiotics as well as acyclovir, but these
   were then discontinued in light of the lack of evidence of infection.
   He also had some angioedema of the tongue while there, which resolved.
   Multiple attempts at LP were made, but were unsuccessful.  He was
   treated empirically with steroids, with no benefit.  He was also found
   to be hyperfcalcemic, and was treated with pamidronate.  He was
   eventually transferred here on [**9-16**] for further evaluation.
         Since being transferred here he has been evaluated by neurology,
   infectious disease, heme-onc and rheumatology.  Bone marrow biopsy has
   been repeated and is pending.  LP was done, but appears to have been a
   very bloody tap, so has not been very helpful diagnostically.  He has
   continued to be febrile daily as high as 103, and has had waxing and
   [**Doctor Last Name 533**] mental status.  Other notable findings have been a very high
   ferritin, declining platelets, declining HCT, and continued
   leukocytosis, although this is trending down as well.  From [**Date range (1) 10680**]
   he had some worsening shortness of breath, and CT of the chest shows
   some peripheral infiltrates and significant lymphadenopathy, including
   a 4cm subcarinal node.  He was transferred to the MICU for hypoxemic
   respiratory failure and was intubated on the day of transfer.

   with tylenol/motrin/cooling blanket.
   NEURO:  No clear cause, likely toxic/metabolic form underlying process,
   but planning repeat MRI brain and spine when stable enough.
   PULMONARY:   Worsening hypoxemia and increased work of breathing.  The
   cause for the infiltrates seen on CT is unclear.  Infection seems
   unlikely in light of his lack of inprovement on antibiotics (which were
   restarted here) and the so far negative work up. The nodular appearance
   and the impressive lymphadenopathy in conjunction with his labs suggest
   some hematologic or inflammatory cause.  Intubated yesterday.
   Increased tachypnea overnight.  Blood gases show adequate oxygenation,
   but he is much more tachycardic, and sats only 93%  on 80%.  Not
   responsive to trials of higher PEEP, and will keep on 8 of PEEP for
   now.  [**Month (only) 51**] need higher sedation to decrease accessory muscles use and
   lower expiratory pressures.
   CV: Hypotension, unclear etiology.  Suspect SIRS picture, although
   whether or not there is infection present is unclear.  Was on levophed
   since yesterday afternoon, but more tachycardica as well. ? adrenal
   insufficiency from rapid steroid taper.  Will try stress dose steroids
   to see if BP improves.  Also will switch pressor to neo to minimize
   tachyphylaxis.  TTE done a few days ago with very poor windows.
   Concerned about valvular disease or tachymyopathy as cause for
   worsening tachycardia.  Will plan for TEE tomorrow.
   ID: All cultures to date are negative, sputum culture pending.  Being
   covered broadly with vanco, pip-tazo, and doxycycline.  ID following
   with us.  Bronch/Bal planned for today.  Parasite smear sent today
   negative. Continue empiric antibiotics
   RHEUM:  The high fevers, lymphadenopathy, very high ferritin and ESR,
   and sweet
s syndrome are all suggestive of some sort of rheumatologic
   process,  Still
s disease can cause may of these findings, but would
   not explain his pulmonary findings or the now-developing hypotension
   and respiratory failure.   The fact that he failed to improved after
   several days of decadron does go against  most rheumatologic causes,

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of lung cancer, spondolithiasis, and myelodysplasia. He was initially admitted to the hospital with fever, cough, and confusion, and was later transferred to the MICU for hypoxemic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Fever: Daily temperatures up to 103°F, with no clear etiology
* Leukocytosis: WBC count of 28.8, with a differential showing 54% neutrophils, 12% bands, 5% lymphocytes, and 17% monocytes
* Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count of 74, with a declining trend
* Hypercalcemia: Calcium level of 8.7 mg/dL, with a history of hypercalcemia and treatment with pamidronate
* Nodular peripheral pulmonary infiltrates: Seen on CT scan, with no clear cause
* Significant mediastinal lymphadenopathy: Seen on CT scan, with no clear cause
* Pancreatic lesion: Seen on CT scan, with no clear cause

The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, with a PEEP of 5 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 80%. His blood gases show adequate oxygenation, but he is tachycardic and hypotensive.

The patient has been treated with antibiotics, steroids, and other medications, but his condition has not improved. He has been diagnosed with Sweet syndrome, a condition characterized by fever, rash, and leukocytosis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis: Given the patient's fever, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia, there is a risk of developing sepsis
* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory arrest
* Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may be signs of cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiomyopathy
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and difficulty responding to stimuli may be signs of neurological complications, such as encephalitis or meningitis
* Hematological complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and leukocytosis may be signs of hematological complications, such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or hemolytic anemia
* Endocrine complications: The patient's hypercalcemia and pancreatic lesion may be signs of endocrine complications, such as hyperparathyroidism or pancreatic cancer

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications. Further diagnostic testing, such as a repeat bone marrow biopsy and a pancreatic lesion biopsy, may be necessary to determine the underlying cause of the patient's condition.

   [**Last Name (LF) 145**],[**First Name3 (LF) **] D.
   Logged Only
   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old gentleman with h/o lung CA s/p resection and no adjuvant
   chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs lung ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.
   # Fever: High fevers with negative blood cultures to date could be
   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.
    - For Infectious Sources
    -- continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, pip-tazo.
    -- change to azithro to doxycycline pending atypical w/u, ehrlichia
   smear
    -- add fungal markers glucan/galactomannan
    -- bronch for BAL, cytology and cultures
    -- f/u ID recs
   - For neoplastic processes
    -- f/u bone marrow biopsy
    -- f/u heme onc recs
    -- we will need to obtain tissue of the lymph node, possibly under
   bronchoscopy if possible. f/u CTS for biopsy
   - IV decadron [**Hospital1 7**] today and then start prednisone 10 mg in AM
   (treatment of Sweets)
   # Hypotension: warm, likely distributive, no clear e/o shock at this
   point
   - IVF for support, alternate LR with saline given hyperchloremia.
   # Altered Mental Status: likely delirium, though cannot r/o
   encephalitis. viral encephalitis serologies are pending. Hypercalcemia
   also contributing, although now corrected. ? carcinoma meningitis.
   - will discuss with IR possibility of cisternal CSF sampling and
   rediscuss with the neurology consulting team.  Presently on hold.
   - if no head MRI at OSH, will need MRI head here today
   # Pneumonia, Atypical vs. Hospital Acquired, hypoxia, increased AA
   gradient. basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious
   process, though certainly this could be neoplastic. Also ? aspiration/
   mucous plugging today
   - BAL today
   - continue vanc/zosyn/doxycycline
   # Back Pain: likely exacerbation of chronic LBP. OSH MRI per d/c
   summary showed no mass/abscess.
   - obtain MRI from OSH for reads here at [**Hospital1 19**]
   # Coagulopathy: Concerning picture for consumptive coagulopathy vs. DIC
   given rising INR, and now presence of schistocytes that are a new
   finding.
   - Will continue supportive care for now.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] fibrinogen
   - consider vitamin K
   # History of Lung Cancer: Unknown type, will seek additional records.
   Lymph node supicious for recurrence or a second malignancy.  Tissue
   diagnosis is needed if marrow bx is unrevealing. Would start with
   subcarinal node first, and potential VATS bx if unrevealing
   # Leukocytosis: still elevated today
   - f/u cultures
   - c. difficile today
   - f/u peripheral flow cytometry here
   - f/u bone marrow bx. At this point, appears stressed marrow reaction,
   but presence of atypical cells is concerning for heme malignancy.
   # Anemia: Elevated ferretin favors anemia of chronic disease.
   - guiaic all stools
   - [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   - active T&S
   # Thrombocytopenia: Given elevated INR, this is likely related to a
   consumptive coagulopathy.  HIT merits consideration given
   hospitalization, though coincidence with rising INR and marrow process
   suggest a more plausible alternate explanation. Her pre-test
   probability [**Doctor Last Name 392**] on 4Ts is 3, and with 0-3 being low will not send
   PF4 test at this time, nor start anticoagulation.
   Also consider vancomycin.
   - trend plts
   - transfuse for active bleeding or plt<10
   # Hypercalcemia: rec'd IV pamidronate, and IV fluids.  PTH is not
   suppressed and is indeed high, suggesting a primary
   hyperparathyroidism. PTHrP pending here.
   - would consider scan for parathyroid adenoma, though will defer this
   and treat hypercalcemia at this point given critical illness.
   # Sweet
s Syndrome / Neutrophilic Dermatoses: likely secondary to a
   second process
   - continuing to taper steroids, with caveat that if pt clinically
   worsens we may need to actually increase steroids. Unclear what is
   being treated at this juncture.
   # FEN
   - NPO for now.
   - Maintenance with NS, alternating with LR.

   [**Last Name (LF) 145**],[**First Name3 (LF) **] D.
   Logged Only
   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old gentleman with h/o lung CA s/p resection and no adjuvant
   chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs lung ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.
   # Fever: High fevers with negative blood cultures to date could be
   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.
    - For Infectious Sources
    -- continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, pip-tazo.
    -- change to azithro to doxycycline pending atypical w/u, ehrlichia
   smear
    -- add fungal markers glucan/galactomannan
    -- bronch for BAL, cytology and cultures
    -- f/u ID recs
   - For neoplastic processes
    -- f/u bone marrow biopsy
    -- f/u heme onc recs
    -- we will need to obtain tissue of the lymph node, possibly under
   bronchoscopy if possible. f/u CTS for biopsy
   - IV decadron [**Hospital1 7**] today and then start prednisone 10 mg in AM
   (treatment of Sweets)
   # Hypotension: warm, likely distributive, no clear e/o shock at this
   point
   - IVF for support, alternate LR with saline given hyperchloremia.
   # Altered Mental Status: likely delirium, though cannot r/o
   encephalitis. viral encephalitis serologies are pending. Hypercalcemia
   also contributing, although now corrected. ? carcinoma meningitis.
   - will discuss with IR possibility of cisternal CSF sampling and
   rediscuss with the neurology consulting team.  Presently on hold.
   - if no head MRI at OSH, will need MRI head here today
   # Pneumonia, Atypical vs. Hospital Acquired, hypoxia, increased AA
   gradient. basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious
   process, though certainly this could be neoplastic. Also ? aspiration/
   mucous plugging today
   - BAL today
   - continue vanc/zosyn/doxycycline
   # Back Pain: likely exacerbation of chronic LBP. OSH MRI per d/c
   summary showed no mass/abscess.
   - obtain MRI from OSH for reads here at [**Hospital1 19**]
   # Coagulopathy: Concerning picture for consumptive coagulopathy vs. DIC
   given rising INR, and now presence of schistocytes that are a new
   finding.
   - Will continue supportive care for now.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] fibrinogen
   - consider vitamin K
   # History of Lung Cancer: Unknown type, will seek additional records.
   Lymph node supicious for recurrence or a second malignancy.  Tissue
   diagnosis is needed if marrow bx is unrevealing. Would start with
   subcarinal node first, and potential VATS bx if unrevealing
   # Leukocytosis: still elevated today
   - f/u cultures
   - c. difficile today
   - f/u peripheral flow cytometry here
   - f/u bone marrow bx. At this point, appears stressed marrow reaction,
   but presence of atypical cells is concerning for heme malignancy.
   # Anemia: Elevated ferretin favors anemia of chronic disease.
   - guiaic all stools
   - [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   - active T&S
   # Thrombocytopenia: Given elevated INR, this is likely related to a
   consumptive coagulopathy.  HIT merits consideration given
   hospitalization, though coincidence with rising INR and marrow process
   suggest a more plausible alternate explanation. Her pre-test
   probability [**Doctor Last Name 392**] on 4Ts is 3, and with 0-3 being low will not send
   PF4 test at this time, nor start anticoagulation.
   Also consider vancomycin.
   - trend plts
   - transfuse for active bleeding or plt<10
   # Hypercalcemia: rec'd IV pamidronate, and IV fluids.  PTH is not
   suppressed and is indeed high, suggesting a primary
   hyperparathyroidism. PTHrP pending here.
   - would consider scan for parathyroid adenoma, though will defer this
   and treat hypercalcemia at this point given critical illness.
   # Sweet
s Syndrome / Neutrophilic Dermatoses: likely secondary to a
   second process
   - continuing to taper steroids, with caveat that if pt clinically
   worsens we may need to actually increase steroids. Unclear what is
   being treated at this juncture.
   # FEN
   - NPO for now.
   - Maintenance with NS, alternating with LR.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of lung cancer who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and anemia/leukocytosis. The patient is currently in the ICU and is being treated for a possible heme malignancy, lung cancer recurrence, or superimposed hospital-acquired pneumonia.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated ferritin (>assay) suggesting hemophagocytic syndrome
* Elevated INR and PTT suggesting a consumptive coagulopathy
* Schistocytes in the blood film, which may indicate a microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
* Leukocytosis with a differential count showing neutrophilia
* Anemia with a high reticulocyte count
* Thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 74,000/μL
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) suggesting liver or bone marrow dysfunction
* Elevated calcium and phosphorus levels, which may indicate hypercalcemia
* Elevated troponin and creatine kinase (CK) levels, which may indicate cardiac damage

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Mediastinal lymphadenopathy on CT scan
* Pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray and CT scan
* No mass or abscess seen on MRI of the brain

The patient's medical history includes:

* History of lung cancer, status post-resection and no adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation therapy
* Chronic lung disease
* Hypercalcemia

The patient's current medications include:

* Piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) for empiric antibiotic therapy
* Vancomycin for empiric antibiotic therapy
* Doxycycline for empiric antibiotic therapy
* Midazolam (Versed) for sedation
* Norepinephrine for vasopressor support
* Fentanyl for pain management
* Pantoprazole (Protonix) for stress ulcer prophylaxis

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Hemophagocytic syndrome
* Consumptive coagulopathy
* Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
* Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura
* Hypercalcemia
* Cardiac damage
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Multi-organ failure

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Empiric antibiotic therapy with broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Supportive care for hypercalcemia, including IV pamidronate and IV fluids
* Monitoring of blood counts, liver function tests, and electrolyte levels
* Consideration of bronchoscopy and mediastinoscopy for tissue diagnosis
* Consideration of chemotherapy and radiation therapy for treatment of lung cancer recurrence or heme malignancy

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple potential medical complications and a high risk of mortality. The patient requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to prevent and manage potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old gentleman with h/o lung CA s/p resection and no adjuvant
   chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs lung ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.
   # Fever: High fevers with negative blood cultures to date could be
   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.
    - For Infectious Sources
    -- continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, pip-tazo.
    -- change to azithro to doxycycline pending atypical w/u, ehrlichia
   smear
    -- add fungal markers glucan/galactomannan
    -- bronch for BAL, cytology and cultures
    -- f/u ID recs
   - For neoplastic processes
    -- f/u bone marrow biopsy
    -- f/u heme onc recs
    -- we will need to obtain tissue of the lymph node, possibly under
   bronchoscopy if possible. f/u CTS for biopsy
   - IV decadron [**Hospital1 7**] today and then start prednisone 10 mg in AM
   (treatment of Sweets)
   # Hypotension: warm, likely distributive, no clear e/o shock at this
   point
   - IVF for support, alternate LR with saline given hyperchloremia.
   # Altered Mental Status: likely delirium, though cannot r/o
   encephalitis. viral encephalitis serologies are pending. Hypercalcemia
   also contributing, although now corrected. ? carcinoma meningitis.
   - will discuss with IR possibility of cisternal CSF sampling and
   rediscuss with the neurology consulting team.  Presently on hold.
   - if no head MRI at OSH, will need MRI head here today
   # Pneumonia, Atypical vs. Hospital Acquired, hypoxia, increased AA
   gradient. basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious
   process, though certainly this could be neoplastic. Also ? aspiration/
   mucous plugging today
   - BAL today
   - continue vanc/zosyn/doxycycline
   # Back Pain: likely exacerbation of chronic LBP. OSH MRI per d/c
   summary showed no mass/abscess.
   - obtain MRI from OSH for reads here at [**Hospital1 19**]
   # Coagulopathy: Concerning picture for consumptive coagulopathy vs. DIC
   given rising INR, and now presence of schistocytes that are a new
   finding.
   - Will continue supportive care for now.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] fibrinogen
   - consider vitamin K
   # History of Lung Cancer: Unknown type, will seek additional records.
   Lymph node supicious for recurrence or a second malignancy.  Tissue
   diagnosis is needed if marrow bx is unrevealing. Would start with
   subcarinal node first, and potential VATS bx if unrevealing
   # Leukocytosis: still elevated today
   - f/u cultures
   - c. difficile today
   - f/u peripheral flow cytometry here
   - f/u bone marrow bx. At this point, appears stressed marrow reaction,
   but presence of atypical cells is concerning for heme malignancy.
   # Anemia: Elevated ferretin favors anemia of chronic disease.
   - guiaic all stools
   - [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   - active T&S
   # Thrombocytopenia: Given elevated INR, this is likely related to a
   consumptive coagulopathy.  HIT merits consideration given
   hospitalization, though coincidence with rising INR and marrow process
   suggest a more plausible alternate explanation. Her pre-test
   probability [**Doctor Last Name 392**] on 4Ts is 3, and with 0-3 being low will not send
   PF4 test at this time, nor start anticoagulation.
   Also consider vancomycin.
   - trend plts
   - transfuse for active bleeding or plt<10
   # Hypercalcemia: rec'd IV pamidronate, and IV fluids.  PTH is not
   suppressed and is indeed high, suggesting a primary
   hyperparathyroidism. PTHrP pending here.
   - would consider scan for parathyroid adenoma, though will defer this
   and treat hypercalcemia at this point given critical illness.
   # Sweet
s Syndrome / Neutrophilic Dermatoses: likely secondary to a
   second process
   - continuing to taper steroids, with caveat that if pt clinically
   worsens we may need to actually increase steroids. Unclear what is
   being treated at this juncture.
   # FEN
   - NPO for now.
   - Maintenance with NS, alternating with LR.
   ICU Care

   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I agree with the
   note above, including the assessment and plan.  To that I would add the
   following:  Mr. [**Known lastname 10650**] remains very ill with respiratory failure,
   fevers, high WBC, hypotension requiring pressors.  We do not have a
   unifying dx at this point
 awaiting bone marrow biopsy final results.
   Unfortunately, he is too sick at this point for mediastinal node
   sampling.  We will continue with ARDSnet ventilation strategy, though I
   am concerned that his left lung is more complaint than R and is seeing
   most of the delivered volume.  Cont current abx regimen.  Also starting
   empiric high dose steroids at 125mg iv SoluMedrol q8hrs given multiple
   possible indications of systemic inflammatory process.  Pt is
   critically ill.  Time spent: 45 minutes.

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, who presents with an acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and anemia/leukocytosis. The patient is critically ill, requiring mechanical ventilation and pressors for hypotension. The patient has a high WBC count, and the differential shows a significant neutrophilic component. The patient has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, and has undergone bronchoscopy with BAL and cultures.

The patient's condition is complicated by the presence of schistocytes in the blood, which suggests a consumptive coagulopathy. The patient's INR is elevated, and the patient has been treated with vitamin K. The patient's platelet count is low, and the patient has been treated with platelet transfusions.

The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray and hypoxia. The patient's mental status is altered, with confusion and disorientation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated ferritin, which suggests anemia of chronic disease. The patient's PTH level is elevated, which suggests primary hyperparathyroidism.

The patient's diagnosis is uncertain, but possible causes include:

* Heme malignancy
* Lung cancer recurrence
* Atypical pneumonia
* Hospital-acquired pneumonia
* Rheumatologic disorder

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Steroids for Sweet's syndrome
* Platelet transfusions
* Vitamin K for coagulopathy
* Mechanical ventilation
* Pressors for hypotension
* Anticoagulation therapy

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Coagulopathy
* Bleeding
* Thrombocytopenia
* Hypercalcemia
* Hyperparathyroidism
* Anemia
* Leukocytosis
* Neutrophilic dermatoses
* Sweet's syndrome

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management in the ICU, with a focus on controlling the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status, and managing the patient's coagulopathy and anemia.

   66 year old gentleman with h/o lung CA s/p resection and no adjuvant
   chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs lung ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.

   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.

    -- f/u bone marrow biopsy

You are a Medical Specialist capable of analyzing complex medical cases.    Assessment and Plan
   66 year old gentleman with h/o lung CA s/p resection and no adjuvant
   chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs lung ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.
   # Fever: High fevers with negative blood cultures to date could be
   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.
    - For Infectious Sources
    -- continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, pip-tazo.
    -- change to azithro to doxycycline pending atypical w/u, ehrlichia
   smear
    -- add fungal markers glucan/galactomannan
    -- bronch for BAL, cytology and cultures
    -- f/u ID recs
   - For neoplastic processes
    -- f/u bone marrow biopsy
    -- f/u heme onc recs
    -- we will need to obtain tissue of the lymph node, possibly under
   bronchoscopy if possible. f/u CTS for biopsy
   - IV decadron [**Hospital1 7**] today and then start prednisone 10 mg in AM
   (treatment of Sweets)
   # Hypotension: warm, likely distributive, no clear e/o shock at this
   point
   - IVF for support, alternate LR with saline given hyperchloremia.
   # Altered Mental Status: likely delirium, though cannot r/o
   encephalitis. viral encephalitis serologies are pending. Hypercalcemia
   also contributing, although now corrected. ? carcinoma meningitis.
   - will discuss with IR possibility of cisternal CSF sampling and
   rediscuss with the neurology consulting team.  Presently on hold.
   - if no head MRI at OSH, will need MRI head here today
   # Pneumonia, Atypical vs. Hospital Acquired, hypoxia, increased AA
   gradient. basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious
   process, though certainly this could be neoplastic. Also ? aspiration/
   mucous plugging today
   - BAL today
   - continue vanc/zosyn/doxycycline
   # Back Pain: likely exacerbation of chronic LBP. OSH MRI per d/c
   summary showed no mass/abscess.
   - obtain MRI from OSH for reads here at [**Hospital1 19**]
   # Coagulopathy: Concerning picture for consumptive coagulopathy vs. DIC
   given rising INR, and now presence of schistocytes that are a new
   finding.
   - Will continue supportive care for now.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] fibrinogen
   - consider vitamin K
   # History of Lung Cancer: Unknown type, will seek additional records.
   Lymph node supicious for recurrence or a second malignancy.  Tissue
   diagnosis is needed if marrow bx is unrevealing. Would start with
   subcarinal node first, and potential VATS bx if unrevealing
   # Leukocytosis: still elevated today
   - f/u cultures
   - c. difficile today
   - f/u peripheral flow cytometry here
   - f/u bone marrow bx. At this point, appears stressed marrow reaction,
   but presence of atypical cells is concerning for heme malignancy.
   # Anemia: Elevated ferretin favors anemia of chronic disease.
   - guiaic all stools
   - [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   - active T&S
   # Thrombocytopenia: Given elevated INR, this is likely related to a
   consumptive coagulopathy.  HIT merits consideration given
   hospitalization, though coincidence with rising INR and marrow process
   suggest a more plausible alternate explanation. Her pre-test
   probability [**Doctor Last Name 392**] on 4Ts is 3, and with 0-3 being low will not send
   PF4 test at this time, nor start anticoagulation.
   Also consider vancomycin.
   - trend plts
   - transfuse for active bleeding or plt<10
   # Hypercalcemia: rec'd IV pamidronate, and IV fluids.  PTH is not
   suppressed and is indeed high, suggesting a primary
   hyperparathyroidism. PTHrP pending here.
   - would consider scan for parathyroid adenoma, though will defer this
   and treat hypercalcemia at this point given critical illness.
   # Sweet
s Syndrome / Neutrophilic Dermatoses: likely secondary to a
   second process
   - continuing to taper steroids, with caveat that if pt clinically
   worsens we may need to actually increase steroids. Unclear what is
   being treated at this juncture.
   # FEN
   - NPO for now.
   - Maintenance with NS, alternating with LR.

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, who is currently admitted to the ICU with acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and anemia/leukocytosis. The patient is being treated for suspected heme malignancy vs. lung cancer recurrence with possible superimposed hospital-acquired pneumonia.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated ferritin (>assay) suggesting hemophagocytic syndrome
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
* Elevated calcium and phosphorus levels
* Leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 28.8 x 10^9/L
* Anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.8 g/dL
* Thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 74 x 10^9/L
* Elevated INR and PTT, suggesting a consumptive coagulopathy

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Fever: high fevers with negative blood cultures to date, suggesting a broad differential diagnosis including neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities
* Pneumonia: atypical vs. hospital-acquired, with basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious process
* Hypercalcemia: rec'd IV pamidronate, and IV fluids, with a high PTH level suggesting primary hyperparathyroidism
* Coagulopathy: concerning picture for consumptive coagulopathy vs. DIC, given rising INR and presence of schistocytes
* Leukocytosis: still elevated today, with a possible stressed marrow reaction or heme malignancy
* Anemia: elevated ferritin favors anemia of chronic disease
* Thrombocytopenia: likely related to consumptive coagulopathy, with a possible HIT consideration

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Broad-spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and doxycycline
* Fungal markers glucan/galactomannan
* Bronchoscopy for BAL, cytology, and cultures
* Bone marrow biopsy
* Heme oncology consultation
* Steroid tapering for Sweet's syndrome/neutrophilic dermatoses
* IV pamidronate for hypercalcemia
* Vitamin K for INR correction
* Fibrinogen replacement
* Anticoagulation therapy for HIT consideration

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: given the patient's underlying lung disease and possible superimposed pneumonia
* Cardiovascular instability: given the patient's hypotension and possible consumptive coagulopathy
* Neurological deterioration: given the patient's altered mental status and possible encephalitis
* Infection: given the patient's fever and possible superimposed pneumonia
* Bleeding: given the patient's thrombocytopenia and possible consumptive coagulopathy
* Organ failure: given the patient's underlying lung disease and possible superimposed pneumonia

Based on the patient's laboratory results and medical conditions, the potential medical complications, and the current treatment plan, the following potential medical complications should be closely monitored and managed:

* Respiratory failure: monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and respiratory rate, and consider intubation if necessary
* Cardiovascular instability: monitor the patient's blood pressure and cardiac rhythm, and consider vasopressors or inotropes if necessary
* Neurological deterioration: monitor the patient's mental status and consider neuroimaging if necessary
* Infection: monitor the patient's temperature and white blood cell count, and consider broad-spectrum antibiotics if necessary
* Bleeding: monitor the patient's platelet count and consider transfusion if necessary
* Organ failure: monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results, and consider dialysis or other supportive therapies if necessary

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old gentleman with h/o lung CA s/p resection and no adjuvant
   chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs lung ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.
   # Fever: High fevers with negative blood cultures to date could be
   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.
    - For Infectious Sources
    -- continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, pip-tazo.
    -- change to azithro to doxycycline pending atypical w/u, ehrlichia
   smear
    -- add fungal markers glucan/galactomannan
    -- bronch for BAL, cytology and cultures
    -- f/u ID recs
   - For neoplastic processes
    -- f/u bone marrow biopsy
    -- f/u heme onc recs
    -- we will need to obtain tissue of the lymph node, possibly under
   bronchoscopy if possible. f/u CTS for biopsy
   - IV decadron [**Hospital1 7**] today and then start prednisone 10 mg in AM
   (treatment of Sweets)
   # Hypotension: warm, likely distributive, no clear e/o shock at this
   point
   - IVF for support, alternate LR with saline given hyperchloremia.
   # Altered Mental Status: likely delirium, though cannot r/o
   encephalitis. viral encephalitis serologies are pending. Hypercalcemia
   also contributing, although now corrected. ? carcinoma meningitis.
   - will discuss with IR possibility of cisternal CSF sampling and
   rediscuss with the neurology consulting team.  Presently on hold.
   - if no head MRI at OSH, will need MRI head here today
   # Pneumonia, Atypical vs. Hospital Acquired, hypoxia, increased AA
   gradient. basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious
   process, though certainly this could be neoplastic. Also ? aspiration/
   mucous plugging today
   - BAL today
   - continue vanc/zosyn/doxycycline
   # Back Pain: likely exacerbation of chronic LBP. OSH MRI per d/c
   summary showed no mass/abscess.
   - obtain MRI from OSH for reads here at [**Hospital1 19**]
   # Coagulopathy: Concerning picture for consumptive coagulopathy vs. DIC
   given rising INR, and now presence of schistocytes that are a new
   finding.
   - Will continue supportive care for now.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] fibrinogen
   - consider vitamin K
   # History of Lung Cancer: Unknown type, will seek additional records.
   Lymph node supicious for recurrence or a second malignancy.  Tissue
   diagnosis is needed if marrow bx is unrevealing. Would start with
   subcarinal node first, and potential VATS bx if unrevealing
   # Leukocytosis: still elevated today
   - f/u cultures
   - c. difficile today
   - f/u peripheral flow cytometry here
   - f/u bone marrow bx. At this point, appears stressed marrow reaction,
   but presence of atypical cells is concerning for heme malignancy.
   # Anemia: Elevated ferretin favors anemia of chronic disease.
   - guiaic all stools
   - [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   - active T&S
   # Thrombocytopenia: Given elevated INR, this is likely related to a
   consumptive coagulopathy.  HIT merits consideration given
   hospitalization, though coincidence with rising INR and marrow process
   suggest a more plausible alternate explanation. Her pre-test
   probability [**Doctor Last Name 392**] on 4Ts is 3, and with 0-3 being low will not send
   PF4 test at this time, nor start anticoagulation.
   Also consider vancomycin.
   - trend plts
   - transfuse for active bleeding or plt<10
   # Hypercalcemia: rec'd IV pamidronate, and IV fluids.  PTH is not
   suppressed and is indeed high, suggesting a primary
   hyperparathyroidism. PTHrP pending here.
   - would consider scan for parathyroid adenoma, though will defer this
   and treat hypercalcemia at this point given critical illness.
   # Sweet
s Syndrome / Neutrophilic Dermatoses: likely secondary to a
   second process
   - continuing to taper steroids, with caveat that if pt clinically
   worsens we may need to actually increase steroids. Unclear what is
   being treated at this juncture.
   # FEN
   - NPO for now.
   - Maintenance with NS, alternating with LR.
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old gentleman with a history of lung cancer, who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and anemia/leukocytosis. The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with several potential diagnoses and complications.

The patient's fever is high, and blood cultures have been negative to date. The enlarged mediastinal nodes suggest a possible lymphoma or myelodysplastic syndrome, while the pulmonary infiltrates could be due to a superimposed pneumonia or neoplastic process. The patient's anemia and leukocytosis are concerning for a possible heme malignancy.

The patient's coagulopathy is concerning, with a rising INR and the presence of schistocytes, which could be indicative of a consumptive coagulopathy or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The patient's platelet count is low, which could be related to the coagulopathy or a separate process.

The patient's hypercalcemia is likely related to a primary hyperparathyroidism, although the patient's PTH is not suppressed, which suggests a possible secondary hyperparathyroidism. The patient's Sweet syndrome/neutrophilic dermatoses is likely secondary to a second process.

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The patient's treatment plan includes antibiotics for suspected pneumonia, antifungal therapy for possible fungal infection, and corticosteroids for possible Sweet syndrome.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's high fever and leukocytosis suggest a possible septic process, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's pulmonary infiltrates and hypoxia could lead to respiratory failure, which could require mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's electrolyte imbalance and coagulopathy could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, which could be life-threatening.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and possible encephalitis could lead to neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and possible DIC could lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, which could be life-threatening.
6. Renal failure: The patient's hypercalcemia and possible electrolyte imbalance could lead to renal failure, which could require dialysis.
7. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state and possible fungal infection could lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The patient's treatment plan should be tailored to address the patient's specific needs and potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old gentleman with h/o carcinoid  lung CA s/p resection and no
   adjuvant chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs carcinoid ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.
   # Fever: High fevers with negative blood cultures to date could be
   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.
    - For Infectious Sources
    -- continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, pip-tazo, doxy
    -- f/u  ehrlichia smear
    -- f/u fungal markers glucan/galactomannan
    -- f/u bronch for BAL, cytology and cultures
    -- f/u ID recs
   - For neoplastic processes
    -- f/u bone marrow biopsy
    -- f/u heme onc recs
   -- endo consult
   -- 600mg motrin alternating with Tylenol for defervese
    -- we will need to obtain tissue of the lymph node, possibly under
   bronchoscopy if possible. f/u CTS for biopsy
   -- start stress dose steroids today for hypotension and potential
   treatment of Sweets
   -possible TEE on tuesday
   # Hypotension: warm, likely distributive, no clear e/o shock at this
   point
   - IVF for support, alternate LR with saline given hyperchloremia
   -switch pressor support  to neo map>55
   -stress dose steroids today for potential adrenal suppression
   # Altered Mental Status: likely delirium, though cannot r/o
   encephalitis. viral encephalitis serologies are pending. Hypercalcemia
   also contributing, although now corrected. ? carcinoma meningitis.
   - will discuss with IR possibility of cisternal CSF sampling and
   rediscuss with the neurology consulting team.  Presently on hold.
   - if no head MRI at OSH, will need MRI head here but will hold off
   given instability
   # Pneumonia, Atypical vs. Hospital Acquired, hypoxia, increased AA
   gradient. basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious
   process, though certainly this could be neoplastic. Also ? aspiration/
   mucous plugging today and ARDS. Working hard to breath on vent.
   - f/u BAL cultures
   -appreciate ID recs
   - continue vanc/zosyn/doxycycline
   - increase PEEP on vent, f/u repeat ABG
   # Back Pain: likely exacerbation of chronic LBP. OSH MRI per d/c
   summary showed no mass/abscess.
   - hold off repeating MRI for now given hemodynamic instability
   # Coagulopathy: Concerning picture for consumptive coagulopathy vs. DIC
   given rising INR, and now presence of schistocytes that are a new
   finding. Platelets falling.
   - f/u HIT antibodies
   - Will continue supportive care for now.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] fibrinogen
   - consider vitamin K for INR>2
   # History of Lung Cancer: OSH show history of carcinoid. Lymph node
   supicious for recurrence or a second malignancy.  Tissue diagnosis is
   needed if marrow bx is unrevealing. Would start with subcarinal node
   first, and potential VATS bx if unrevealing.
   -d/w IP
   # Leukocytosis: still elevated today
   - f/u cultures
   - c. difficile today
   - f/u peripheral flow cytometry here
   - f/u bone marrow bx. At this point, appears stressed marrow reaction,
   but presence of atypical cells is concerning for heme malignancy.
   -appreciate heme/onc recs
   # Anemia: Elevated ferretin favors anemia of chronic disease. Potential
   source of bleeding include gastritis.
   - guiaic all stools
   - [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   - active T&S
   # Thrombocytopenia: Given elevated INR, this is likely related to a
   consumptive coagulopathy.  HIT merits consideration given
   hospitalization, though coincidence with rising INR and marrow process
   suggest a more plausible alternate explanation. Her pre-test
   probability [**Doctor Last Name 392**] on 4Ts is 3, and with 0-3 being low will not send
   PF4 test at this time, nor start anticoagulation.
   Also consider vancomycin.
   - trend plts
   - transfuse for active bleeding or plt<10
   -f/u hit antibodies
   # Hypercalcemia: rec'd IV pamidronate, and IV fluids.  PTH is not
   suppressed and is indeed high, suggesting a primary
   hyperparathyroidism. PTHrP pending here.
   -endo consult today
   - would consider scan for parathyroid adenoma, though will defer this
   and treat hypercalcemia at this point given critical illness.
   # Sweet
s Syndrome / Neutrophilic Dermatoses: likely secondary to a
   second process
   - stress dosed steroid for now
   # FEN
   - starting tube feeds today
   - Maintenance with NS, alternating with LR.
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of carcinoid lung cancer, who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and anemia/leukocytosis. The patient's condition is concerning for heme malignancy, carcinoid tumor recurrence, or superimposed hospital-acquired pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death if not promptly treated.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and increased A-a gradient indicate respiratory failure, which can be exacerbated by the patient's underlying lung disease and potential pneumonia.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's rising INR and schistocytes suggest a consumptive coagulopathy, which can lead to bleeding and thrombosis if not managed promptly.
4. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may be related to the underlying disease process or secondary to bleeding or consumptive coagulopathy.
5. Hypercalcemia: The patient's hypercalcemia can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, kidney damage, and neurologic symptoms if not treated promptly.
6. Sweet syndrome/neutrophilic dermatoses: The patient's skin lesions may be related to a secondary process, which can lead to skin necrosis and systemic complications if not managed promptly.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's pulmonary infiltrates and hypoxia suggest the possibility of pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure and death if not treated promptly.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and potential cardiac arrhythmias suggest the possibility of cardiac complications, which can lead to cardiac arrest and death if not managed promptly.

Based on the patient's condition, the following assessments and plans are recommended:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential bacterial and fungal pathogens.
2. Perform bronchoscopy to obtain tissue samples for cytology and cultures.
3. Consider endoscopy to obtain tissue samples for cytology and cultures.
4. Continue stress dose steroids for potential adrenal suppression.
5. Monitor the patient's coagulation status and platelet count to prevent bleeding and thrombosis.
6. Consider vitamin K for INR > 2 to prevent bleeding.
7. Monitor the patient's glycemic control to prevent hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
8. Consider parathyroid scan to evaluate for primary hyperparathyroidism.
9. Continue stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. Monitor the patient's mental status to prevent delirium and encephalopathy.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old gentleman with h/o carcinoid  lung CA s/p resection and no
   adjuvant chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs carcinoid ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.
   # Fever: High fevers with negative blood cultures to date could be
   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.
    - For Infectious Sources
    -- continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, pip-tazo, doxy
    -- f/u  ehrlichia smear
    -- f/u fungal markers glucan/galactomannan
    -- f/u bronch for BAL, cytology and cultures
    -- f/u ID recs
   - For neoplastic processes
    -- f/u bone marrow biopsy
    -- f/u heme onc recs
   -- endo consult
   -- 600mg motrin alternating with Tylenol for defervese
    -- we will need to obtain tissue of the lymph node, possibly under
   bronchoscopy if possible. f/u CTS for biopsy
   -- start stress dose steroids today for hypotension and potential
   treatment of Sweets
   -possible TEE on tuesday
   # Hypotension: warm, likely distributive, no clear e/o shock at this
   point
   - IVF for support, alternate LR with saline given hyperchloremia
   -switch pressor support  to neo map>55
   -stress dose steroids today for potential adrenal suppression
   # Altered Mental Status: likely delirium, though cannot r/o
   encephalitis. viral encephalitis serologies are pending. Hypercalcemia
   also contributing, although now corrected. ? carcinoma meningitis.
   - will discuss with IR possibility of cisternal CSF sampling and
   rediscuss with the neurology consulting team.  Presently on hold.
   - if no head MRI at OSH, will need MRI head here but will hold off
   given instability
   # Pneumonia, Atypical vs. Hospital Acquired, hypoxia, increased AA
   gradient. basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious
   process, though certainly this could be neoplastic. Also ? aspiration/
   mucous plugging today and ARDS. Working hard to breath on vent.
   - f/u BAL cultures
   -appreciate ID recs
   - continue vanc/zosyn/doxycycline
   - increase PEEP on vent, f/u repeat ABG
   # Back Pain: likely exacerbation of chronic LBP. OSH MRI per d/c
   summary showed no mass/abscess.
   - hold off repeating MRI for now given hemodynamic instability
   # Coagulopathy: Concerning picture for consumptive coagulopathy vs. DIC
   given rising INR, and now presence of schistocytes that are a new
   finding. Platelets falling.
   - f/u HIT antibodies
   - Will continue supportive care for now.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] fibrinogen
   - consider vitamin K for INR>2
   # History of Lung Cancer: OSH show history of carcinoid. Lymph node
   supicious for recurrence or a second malignancy.  Tissue diagnosis is
   needed if marrow bx is unrevealing. Would start with subcarinal node
   first, and potential VATS bx if unrevealing.
   -d/w IP
   # Leukocytosis: still elevated today
   - f/u cultures
   - c. difficile today
   - f/u peripheral flow cytometry here
   - f/u bone marrow bx. At this point, appears stressed marrow reaction,
   but presence of atypical cells is concerning for heme malignancy.
   -appreciate heme/onc recs
   # Anemia: Elevated ferretin favors anemia of chronic disease. Potential
   source of bleeding include gastritis.
   - guiaic all stools
   - [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   - active T&S
   # Thrombocytopenia: Given elevated INR, this is likely related to a
   consumptive coagulopathy.  HIT merits consideration given
   hospitalization, though coincidence with rising INR and marrow process
   suggest a more plausible alternate explanation. Her pre-test
   probability [**Doctor Last Name 392**] on 4Ts is 3, and with 0-3 being low will not send
   PF4 test at this time, nor start anticoagulation.
   Also consider vancomycin.
   - trend plts
   - transfuse for active bleeding or plt<10
   -f/u hit antibodies
   # Hypercalcemia: rec'd IV pamidronate, and IV fluids.  PTH is not
   suppressed and is indeed high, suggesting a primary
   hyperparathyroidism. PTHrP pending here.
   -endo consult today
   - would consider scan for parathyroid adenoma, though will defer this
   and treat hypercalcemia at this point given critical illness.
   # Sweet
s Syndrome / Neutrophilic Dermatoses: likely secondary to a
   second process
   - stress dosed steroid for now

   - starting tube feeds today

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of carcinoid lung cancer, who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and anemia/leukocytosis. He is suspected to have heme malignancy or carcinoid cancer recurrence with possible superimposed hospital-acquired pneumonia. The patient has developed hypotension, requiring pressor support, and altered mental status, possibly due to delirium or encephalitis. He also has pneumonia, atypical or hospital-acquired, and increased alveolar-arterial gradient. The patient has a concerning coagulopathy with rising INR and schistocytes, and platelets are falling. He has a history of lung cancer and is suspected to have lymph node involvement.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and altered mental status suggest a possible septic process.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's rising INR, schistocytes, and falling platelets indicate a consumptive coagulopathy, which may be related to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or a consumptive coagulopathy due to a primary disorder.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's pulmonary infiltrates and increased alveolar-arterial gradient suggest a possible pneumonia, which may be atypical or hospital-acquired.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be related to sepsis, hypovolemia, or distributive shock.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to delirium, encephalitis, or hypercalcemia.
6. Hypercalcemia: The patient's hypercalcemia may be related to primary hyperparathyroidism or a secondary disorder.
7. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be related to a primary disorder or a response to infection.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be related to a consumptive coagulopathy or a primary disorder.
9. Carcinoid syndrome: The patient's history of carcinoid lung cancer and the presence of carcinoid syndrome symptoms suggest a possible carcinoid syndrome recurrence.
10. Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH): The patient's elevated ferritin and the presence of atypical cells in the bone marrow biopsy suggest a possible HLH.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to address these potential complications.

   66 year old gentleman with h/o carcinoid  lung CA s/p resection and no
   adjuvant chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs carcinoid ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.
   # Fever: High fevers with negative blood cultures to date could be
   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.

    -- continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, pip-tazo, doxy

   -- 600mg motrin alternating with Tylenol for defervese
    -- we will need to obtain tissue of the lymph node, possibly under
   bronchoscopy if possible. f/u CTS for biopsy
   -- start stress dose steroids today for hypotension and potential
   treatment of Sweets
   -possible TEE on tuesday

   - IVF for support, alternate LR with saline given hyperchloremia

   # Altered Mental Status: likely delirium, though cannot r/o

   also contributing, although now corrected. ? carcinoma meningitis.
   - will discuss with IR possibility of cisternal CSF sampling and
   rediscuss with the neurology consulting team.  Presently on hold.
   - if no head MRI at OSH, will need MRI head here but will hold off
   given instability
   # Pneumonia, Atypical vs. Hospital Acquired, hypoxia, increased AA
   gradient. basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious
   process, though certainly this could be neoplastic. Also ? aspiration/
   mucous plugging today and ARDS. Working hard to breath on vent.
   - f/u BAL cultures
   -appreciate ID recs

   supicious for recurrence or a second malignancy.  Tissue diagnosis is

   first, and potential VATS bx if unrevealing.

   - f/u bone marrow bx. At this point, appears stressed marrow reaction,
   but presence of atypical cells is concerning for heme malignancy.
   -appreciate heme/onc recs
   # Anemia: Elevated ferretin favors anemia of chronic disease. Potential
   source of bleeding include gastritis.
   - guiaic all stools
   - [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   - active T&S
   # Thrombocytopenia: Given elevated INR, this is likely related to a
   consumptive coagulopathy.  HIT merits consideration given
   hospitalization, though coincidence with rising INR and marrow process
   suggest a more plausible alternate explanation. Her pre-test
   probability [**Doctor Last Name 392**] on 4Ts is 3, and with 0-3 being low will not send

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of carcinoid lung cancer who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and anemia/leukocytosis. He is currently in the ICU with hypotension, tachycardia, and increasing lactate levels. The patient has a high fever with negative blood cultures, and the differential diagnosis includes neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. The patient is also experiencing coagulopathy, with rising INR and schistocytes, and has a history of lung cancer with suspicion of recurrence or a second malignancy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic Shock: The patient's hypotension and tachycardia may be indicative of septic shock, which can be life-threatening if not promptly treated.
2. ARDS: The patient's pulmonary infiltrates and hypoxia may be indicative of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), which can lead to respiratory failure.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's rising INR and schistocytes may indicate a consumptive coagulopathy, which can lead to bleeding complications.
4. Hypercalcemia: The patient's hypercalcemia may be a result of primary hyperparathyroidism, which can lead to complications such as cardiac arrhythmias and renal failure.
5. Heme Malignancy: The patient's elevated ferritin and presence of atypical cells in the bone marrow may indicate a heme malignancy, which can lead to a poor prognosis.
6. Carcinoid Syndrome: The patient's history of carcinoid lung cancer and suspicion of recurrence or a second malignancy may indicate a carcinoid syndrome, which can lead to a range of complications including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and neurological symptoms.
7. Sepsis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis may indicate sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure if not promptly treated.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management. The plan includes:

1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics for potential infections
2. Stress dose steroids for potential adrenal suppression
3. IVF for support
4. Pressor support with neo-methyl-DOPA
5. Consideration of TEE on Tuesday
6. Bone marrow biopsy to determine presence of heme malignancy
7. Endo consult for potential parathyroid adenoma
8. Consideration of vitamin K for INR > 2
9. Fibrinogen levels to monitor coagulopathy
10. Repeat ABG to monitor respiratory status
11. Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) mutation testing to rule out cystic fibrosis
12. Consideration of cisternal CSF sampling and MRI head if instability improves.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management, and the plan will need to be adjusted based on the patient's response to treatment and the results of further testing.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old gentleman with h/o carcinoid  lung CA s/p resection and no
   adjuvant chemo/XRT who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal
   lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and
   anemia/leukocytosis concerning for heme malignancy vs carcinoid ca
   recurrence with possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired
   pneumonia.
   # Fever: High fevers with negative blood cultures to date could be
   broad between neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities. Given
   the enlarged mediastinal nodes, this could be lymphoma/myelodyscrasia,
   adenoca of lung or pancreas, squamous ca, or a reactive process to
   infection. The pulmonary infiltrates suggest a superimposed pneumonic
   process, that could be bacterial, or less likely eosinophilic pneumonia
   or fungal pneumonia. DAH or DIP is less likely given distribution.
   Given elevated ferritin >assay ([**2112**]), HLH/hemophagocytic syndrome
   merits consideration. BM bx pending for presence. This is doubtfult to
   be primary sweets, and the neutrophilic dermatosis seen on OSH is
   likely secondary to the as of yet undetermined process.
    - For Infectious Sources
    -- continue broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin, pip-tazo, doxy
    -- f/u  ehrlichia smear
    -- f/u fungal markers glucan/galactomannan
    -- f/u bronch for BAL, cytology and cultures
    -- f/u ID recs
   - For neoplastic processes
    -- f/u bone marrow biopsy
    -- f/u heme onc recs
   -- endo consult
   -- 600mg motrin alternating with Tylenol for defervese
    -- we will need to obtain tissue of the lymph node, possibly under
   bronchoscopy if possible. f/u CTS for biopsy
   -- start stress dose steroids today for hypotension and potential
   treatment of Sweets
   -possible TEE on tuesday
   # Hypotension: warm, likely distributive, no clear e/o shock at this
   point
   - IVF for support, alternate LR with saline given hyperchloremia
   -switch pressor support  to neo map>55
   -stress dose steroids today for potential adrenal suppression
    #Acute renal failure
   -U/A, urine lytes
   # Altered Mental Status: likely delirium, though cannot r/o
   encephalitis. viral encephalitis serologies are pending. Hypercalcemia
   also contributing, although now corrected. ? carcinoma meningitis.
   - will discuss with IR possibility of cisternal CSF sampling and
   rediscuss with the neurology consulting team.  Presently on hold.
   - if no head MRI at OSH, will need MRI head here but will hold off
   given instability
   # Pneumonia, Atypical vs. Hospital Acquired, hypoxia, increased AA
   gradient. basilar infiltrates suspicious for superimposed infectious
   process, though certainly this could be neoplastic. Also ? aspiration/
   mucous plugging today and ARDS. Working hard to breath on vent.
   - f/u BAL cultures
   -appreciate ID recs
   - continue vanc/zosyn/doxycycline
   - increase PEEP on vent, f/u repeat ABG
   # Back Pain: likely exacerbation of chronic LBP. OSH MRI per d/c
   summary showed no mass/abscess.
   - hold off repeating MRI for now given hemodynamic instability
   # Coagulopathy: Concerning picture for consumptive coagulopathy vs. DIC
   given rising INR, and now presence of schistocytes that are a new
   finding. Platelets falling.
   - f/u HIT antibodies
   - Will continue supportive care for now.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] fibrinogen
   - consider vitamin K for INR>2
   # History of Lung Cancer: OSH show history of carcinoid. Lymph node
   supicious for recurrence or a second malignancy.  Tissue diagnosis is
   needed if marrow bx is unrevealing. Would start with subcarinal node
   first, and potential VATS bx if unrevealing.
   -d/w IP

   - f/u peripheral flow cytometry here
   - f/u bone marrow bx. At this point, appears stressed marrow reaction,
   but presence of atypical cells is concerning for heme malignancy.
   -appreciate heme/onc recs
   # Anemia: Elevated ferretin favors anemia of chronic disease. Potential
   source of bleeding include gastritis.
   - guiaic all stools
   - [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   - active T&S
   # Thrombocytopenia: Given elevated INR, this is likely related to a
   consumptive coagulopathy.  HIT merits consideration given
   hospitalization, though coincidence with rising INR and marrow process
   suggest a more plausible alternate explanation. Her pre-test
   probability [**Doctor Last Name 392**] on 4Ts is 3, and with 0-3 being low will not send

   -endo consult today

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of carcinoid lung cancer, who presented with acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion, and anemia/leukocytosis. He has been diagnosed with a probable heme malignancy or carcinoid cancer recurrence, with the possibility of superimposed hospital-acquired pneumonia. He is currently receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics and has been started on stress dose steroids for potential adrenal suppression.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient's high fever and leukocytosis suggest a possible septic process, which can lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and even death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and hypoxia can worsen, leading to respiratory failure and the need for mechanical ventilation.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and decreased urine output suggest acute kidney injury, which can worsen with continued hypotension and fluid overload.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's elevated INR and schistocytes suggest a consumptive coagulopathy, which can lead to bleeding and organ failure.
5. Hypercalcemia: The patient's high calcium levels can worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, neuromuscular weakness, and renal failure.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
7. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers suggest a possible infection, which can spread to other parts of the body.
8. Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH): The patient's elevated ferritin and triglycerides suggest a possible HLH, which can lead to multi-organ failure and death.
9. Malignancy progression: The patient's heme malignancy or carcinoid cancer recurrence can progress, leading to worsening symptoms and poor prognosis.
10. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's hypotension and electrolyte imbalances suggest a possible adrenal insufficiency, which can worsen with continued stress and glucocorticoid withdrawal.

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of carcinoid lung cancer, who presents with acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and anemia/leukocytosis. He has a high risk of heme malignancy vs. carcinoid cancer recurrence, as well as hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS. He is also experiencing distributive shock, acute renal failure, altered mental status, back pain, coagulopathy, leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS: The patient's oxygenation is difficult to manage, and he requires high levels of oxygen to maintain a PO2 > 80.
2. Infection: The patient has high fevers and negative blood cultures, which could be due to a broad range of infectious agents, including neoplastic, infectious, and rheumatologic entities.
3. Hemophagocytic syndrome (HLH): The patient's elevated ferritin levels and lymphadenopathy suggest a high risk of HLH, which is a life-threatening condition.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a consumptive coagulopathy, which is likely related to his marrow process and may be exacerbated by his infection and inflammation.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is at risk of developing acute kidney injury.
6. Altered mental status: The patient's delirium may be due to his underlying condition, infection, or medication side effects.
7. Back pain: The patient's back pain may be due to an exacerbation of his chronic lower back pain or a new condition.
8. Coagulopathy: The patient's INR is elevated, and he has schistocytes, which suggests a consumptive coagulopathy or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
9. Neutrophilic dermatoses: The patient has a neutrophilic dermatosis, which may be secondary to his underlying condition or a new process.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential infections.
2. Perform a bronchoscopy to evaluate the patient's pulmonary infiltrates and obtain tissue samples for pathology.
3. Consider a bone marrow biopsy to evaluate the patient's marrow process and rule out heme malignancy.
4. Monitor the patient's coagulation parameters and transfuse platelets as necessary.
5. Consider vitamin K for INR > 2.
6. Continue stress-dose steroids to manage the patient's inflammation and potential HLH.
7. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.
8. Consider a cisternal CSF sampling to evaluate the patient's altered mental status.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygenation and adjust his respiratory support as necessary.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of carcinoid lung cancer, who presented with an acute febrile illness, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates, confusion/delirium, and anemia/leukocytosis. The patient is currently in the ICU with a diagnosis of hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and stress-dose steroids.

The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's oxygenation is difficult to maintain, and he requires high levels of oxygen support.
2. Fever: The patient has high fevers, which are not responding to antibiotics, and may be related to a neoplastic or infectious process.
3. Altered mental status: The patient is experiencing confusion and delirium, which may be related to hypercalcemia, encephalitis, or a metabolic disorder.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a consumptive coagulopathy, which is likely related to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH).
5. Leukocytosis: The patient has an elevated white blood cell count, which may be related to a stress reaction or a neoplastic process.
6. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be related to bleeding or a chronic disease process.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count, which may be related to a consumptive coagulopathy or a bone marrow disorder.
8. Hypercalcemia: The patient has hypercalcemia, which may be related to a primary hyperparathyroidism or a secondary process.

The patient's medical team is considering several potential diagnoses, including:

1. Carcinoid syndrome recurrence
2. Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)
3. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
4. Neoplastic process, such as lymphoma or leukemia
5. Infection, such as sepsis or pneumonia
6. Autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics
2. Stress-dose steroids
3. Vasopressors to support blood pressure
4. Oxygen therapy to support oxygenation
5. Blood transfusions to support anemia and thrombocytopenia
6. Platelet transfusions to support thrombocytopenia
7. Vitamin K to support coagulation
8. Fibrinogen replacement therapy to support coagulation
9. Corticosteroids to support hypercalcemia
10. Bone marrow biopsy to evaluate for neoplastic process

The patient's medical team is also considering several potential complications, including:

1. Sepsis
2. ARDS
3. DIC
4. HLH
5. Bleeding
6. Thrombosis
7. Infection
8. Autoimmune disorder

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve outcomes.
